bug.author: mbh86
bug.summary: NaT in date columns make histograme go crazy
bug.description:
Hello, I am referencing issue 111, which happens again in version 2.8.0 <denchmark-code>import pandas as pd import pandas_profiling import numpy as np
def test_issue_111(): years = pd.Series(["{:02d}/01/{}".format(x, y) for x in range(1989, 2020) for y in range(1, 30)])
df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randint(0, len(years), size=(len(years), 4)), columns=list('ABCD')) df['E'] = pd.to_datetime(years) df['E'].iloc[10:100] = pd.NaT
report = df.profile_report() report.to_file('test.html') </denchmark-code>
From the post by @sbrugman in #111 (comment)

comments.comment: Hi <denchmark-link:https://github.com/mbh86>@mbh86</denchmark-link> , thanks for opening a new issue. I'm looking into this for the next release. In the meantime: could you add a screencapture with the current histogram and the expected result?

Hi <denchmark-link:https://github.com/sbrugman>@sbrugman</denchmark-link> , here is the current result: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10547700/86766959-8b473000-c04b-11ea-9e26-1456b0fabb8f.png></denchmark-link>
And the expected result is: (which I obtain when I filter out missing values in the dataframe) <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10547700/86768567-16c1c080-c04e-11ea-8fcb-e16a4086a49e.png></denchmark-link>
I've worked on precomputing histograms in parallel. This included your bug report in the refactor, and it should be fixed in the next release.

The v2.9.0rc1 release is out, and should resolve this issue. Until this version is fully released, you can install it via pip in the following way: <denchmark-code>pip install --pre -U pandas-profiling </denchmark-code>
It would be very helpful to know if the release candidate adequately solves the issue.
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/sbrugman>@sbrugman</denchmark-link> , I tested it and it works, thank you.
